item.title: HR4U - Human Resource Management System
item.description:
HR4U - Human Resource Management System

A comprehensive Human Resource Management System built to streamline workforce management, attendance tracking, payroll processing, and employee lifecycle management.

Key Features

  • Employee Management: Complete employee lifecycle from onboarding to exit
  • Attendance Tracking: Real-time attendance monitoring with biometric integration
  • Leave Management: Automated leave application and approval workflow
  • Payroll Processing: Automated salary calculation with tax and deduction management
  • Performance Reviews: Structured performance evaluation system
  • Reports & Analytics: Comprehensive HR reports and dashboards

Technologies Used

  • Backend: PHP Laravel
  • Frontend: Vue.js, Alpine.js
  • Database: MySQL
  • API: RESTful API architecture

Outcome

Successfully deployed across multiple organizations, managing 1000+ employees with improved HR efficiency by 60%.

item.title: Building Scalable HRMS with Laravel and Vue.js
item.description:
Building Scalable HRMS with Laravel and Vue.js

Human Resource Management Systems (HRMS) are complex applications that require careful planning and architecture. In this post, I’ll share my experience building scalable HRMS solutions.

Architecture Considerations

When building an HRMS, consider these key architectural decisions:

  1. Modular Design: Break down the system into modules (Employee, Attendance, Payroll, Leave)
  2. API-First Approach: Build RESTful APIs that can serve multiple clients
  3. Database Design: Proper normalization and indexing for performance
  4. Security: Multi-tenant architecture with role-based access control

Laravel Backend Structure

// Example of a clean controller structure
class EmployeeController extends Controller
{
    public function __construct(
        private EmployeeService $employeeService
    ) {}

    public function index(Request $request)
    {
        return $this->employeeService->getPaginated(
            $request->validated()
        );
    }
}
